Sasha, perhaps those without formal qualifications feel the effects of a lumbering, grossly expensive, inefficient bureaucracy more acutely than those with such qualifications.  The former may be unemployed (along with many thousands of graduates), self-employed or small business owners who have observed that the EU has shown itself incapable of change and has become more ineffective, the larger it has become - and it's still expanding.......  One could expect effective decision-making from an Executive of 5 members (as the EU was originally) but 28? Never!  The EU may be staffed by thousands of talented, well-meaning people but the shear size of the Union makes timely, effective, decision-making impossible. Could you get a family of 28 members to agree on anything?  One doesn't need a degree to know that butter mountains, beef mountains and wine-lakes are not symptomatic of an efficiently run business. What remains to be seen is whether an EU with one less state can concur on how to respond to the UK's leave-request, or not.  Incidentally, I have two degrees (a BA and a B.Sc) but I still don't like my tax contributions being sucked into a big black hole.  I'd rather see it spent where I can see its effects e.g. on improving our country's education and health/care systems, the NHS, agriculture, emergency and security services, transport etc - and where there is some prospect of being able to hold policy-makers to account when they make poor decisions.
